sen.e: After the middle of the Heian period, genin appeared as a name that stood for privately subordinative people employed inside the houses of their masters, such as nobles, temples, shrines and tato (cultivators).

sen.e: In general, however, genin was more slavish to his or her master's house than shoju, and shoju was a name that was more often used in samurai families.
